title: Puzzled Pint brews fun with brainteasers, craft beer
text:
Puzzled Pint brews fun with brainteasers, craft beer By Robert Allen, Detroit Free Press 11:31 a.m. EDT October 8, 2015 Puzzled Pint, a monthly puzzle-solving bar game, arrives Oct. 13 somewhere in metro Detroit. To find the location, you must first solve a puzzle. (Photo: Matt Cleinman, Puzzled Pint / courtesy photo) 4 CONNECT 10 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
Odd puzzles and beer drinking make for brain-twisting fun at a bar-based game that's spread to several trendy cities and is coming to metro Detroit next week. 
Puzzled Pint is free, beginner-friendly and craft-beer-friendly. There are no prizes. You can play on a team, use a smartphone and it's not really competitive. 
To find out where the monthly event will be held, you must first solve a puzzle on the game's website, PuzzledPint.com . But there are plenty of hints to keep you from being left out. Specialized knowledge isn't required. 
"They are often direction-less, and may incorporate traditional puzzles like crosswords, word searches, cryptograms, jigsaw puzzles, word play and logic problems. If you like any sort of logic or word puzzle, you’ll like these," according to the Puzzled Pint website. 
Raymond Eifler, 50, of Farmington and Steve Gross, 48, of Northville decided to start Puzzled Pint here and show people the "joy of puzzling," Eifler says, through an easier, sociable alternative to more-competitive puzzle games. People who like board games and trivia nights might enjoy it. 
"Trivia is like, 'Can you remember this?' but puzzle is, 'Hey, can you figure out this tricky, cool thing?' " Eifler said. 
Puzzled Pint started in Portland, Ore., in 2010, and is now played in Chicago, San Francisco, London (England), Brooklyn (New York), Boston, Seattle, Vienna (Austria) and Auckland (New Zealand), among a growing number of cities. The same puzzles are worked in all the cities the second Tuesday of every month, and the puzzle to find the location is released on the Puzzled Pint website the preceding Friday. San Francisco solving away! pic.twitter.com/YFIIxIud8R — Puzzled Pint (@PuzzledPint) June 10, 2015 
Eifler, who's spent more than 20 years working in information-technology management, and Gross, a marketing manager for an automotive semiconductor company, plan to hold the event at a number of bars across metro Detroit. The first one is Oct. 13 in Livonia (the city being the only hint they shared). 
"We'll only hold it at pubs that have craft beer, because that's near and dear to our heart, the Michigan craft beer movement," Eifler said. 
People of all ages above 21 are welcome. Gross said there's a four-hour time limit to solve the puzzles, but the average solving time is about 1½ hours. 
Matt Cleinman, one of the Puzzled Pint's cofounders, said in an e-mail that the puzzles could be compared to the types used in games MIT Mystery Hunt, DASH and the Game. Spirits of Detroit
